The acute inflammation caused by the crystals may give rise to general signs (fever, even chills) and an acute biological inflammatory syndrome (elevated CRP, even VS, hyperleucocytosis).

If these signs are present, a joint infection must be ruled out.

However, they may also correspond to an associated infection, the classic trigger for a gout attack. This clinical picture explains the number of emergency visits and hospitalisations.

question.title: What is the primary indication for ruling out a joint infection in the context of acute inflammation caused by microcrystalline arthropathies?

option_b.title: A joint infection
option_b.description: Associated infection that triggers a gout attack

option_c.title: A classic trigger for a gout attack
option_c.description: The primary indication for ruling out a joint infection

option_d.title: A general sign of acute inflammation
option_d.description: The primary indication for ruling out a joint infection
